bibl.title: Letter from James Carroll to L. O. Howard, February 10, 1901

div1.p: Carroll notifies Howard that he is sending him a bumblebee, and he regrets that there are no flies available to send, as the place where he is has been completely sewered and disinfected. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from James Carroll to L. O. Howard, February 10, 1901
div1.opener:
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES OF THE UNITED STATES
* 1934 *
[unclear]
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Washington, D. C.
RECORDS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE, Bureau of
Entomology and Plant Quarantine.
Three Centimeters
Camp Columbia, Cuba,
February 10, 1901.
DIVISION OF ENTOMOLOGY
* FEB 14 1901 *
Answered by Letter
Dear Dr Howard:
div1.p:
I take the
liberty of sending you by
mail today what appears
to be a negro bumble-bee.

I suppose they are common
as dirt but I have never
seen one before and as it
was no trouble to pack it
thought I would do so.

Dr Reed will give you
all the news as soon as
this could reach you.

I am sorry I could not
send the flies you desired
but this place is so thoroughly
severed and disinfected
that open sinks are a
great rarity.
div1.closer:
With kind regards and
hoping to see you soon,
Very sincerely yours, James Carroll Dr L. O. Howard,
Washington, D.C.
